Monster Farm Online Developer's Blog
Monster Rancher Metropolis: The Cafe: Archived Topics From Prior Years: Year 2007 Topics (Year of the Goldfish Bowl): Monster Farm Online Developer's Blog
By RPGDesigner on Thursday, April 5, 2007 - 10:23 am:

http://www.mf-online.jp/com_blog_entry.aspx

How do you like that? They've been updating consistently since
March. I guess Monster Farm Channel isn't as accurate as it used to
be now that MR development is being outsourced.

Anyway, the blog entries show off a number of new breeds, as well
as the new designs of current breeds. At least six or seven new
species have been introduced.

The official site has also been updated with new monsters, playable
characters and NPCs.

By Lisa Shock on Thursday, April 5, 2007 - 04:09 pm:

Nice find, looks like Tecmo's main JP page just started pointing to it.

It's still really hard to tell anything about a game until you've played, though.

By RPGDesigner on Friday, April 6, 2007 - 02:48 am:

I managed to gather at least two things from the earlier blog
entries;

First, monsters' physical appearances will change depending on
how they are raised, making every monster unique. (Examples in
the latest blog entry (Those aren't subtypes, as I suspected earlier)).

Secondly, according to the GM, a large number of classic breeds
will be returning in addition to the numerous new ones. When
asked if Worm or Monol would "possibly" be amongst them, he
answered "Of course!". The key word here is "possibly"; he did not
confirm anything.

By fiffa46 on Friday, April 6, 2007 - 09:04 am:

man I wish I knew how to read that. >.<

By RPGDesigner on Friday, April 6, 2007 - 02:54 pm:

New entry for today has an interview. Most of it is really hard to
figure out, but I managed to decipher the following:

Once again, the monsters won't be dying. However, they'll reach
a point where they won't get any stronger.

You'll be training one monster at a time, but can have access to
more than one. (Not 100% clear on this one, frankly)

There won't be any monster trading, yet online PvP battling is
pretty much certain.

You'll be able to create/join a party of persons with their
monsters to go on large-scale ventures, as is the status quo of
most MMOs.

By RPGDesigner on Friday, April 6, 2007 - 03:04 pm:

Ah, yes, I think I've got that second one. It looks like you can raise
multiple monsters, yet can only take one with you at a time. Thus,
you won't be forced to raise several to get anywhere.

By RPGDesigner on Friday, April 6, 2007 - 03:21 pm:

Oh, before I forget, I found a special message on the official site.

It stated that they're planning for a Spring release in Japan, along
with a number of cryptic messages, one of them hinting at a new/
alternate method of Monster regeneration.

By Lisa Shock on Wednesday, April 11, 2007 - 08:03 pm:

It says you'll be able to use CD-Roms, DVDs, in-game stones, and just plain choose types of monsters you want. However, each time, the stats will differ.

By Lisa Shock on Thursday, April 12, 2007 - 08:27 am:

By Blulightning on Friday, April 13, 2007 - 01:06 am:

Recently there have been a lot of U.S. companies buying the licenses to a lot of MMO-style games, usually developed by small Korean companies, and providing cheap servers for them.
It seems to be one of the new marketing trends lately.

I'm not saying it will happen, but there is a very small chance, I think.
Although, I do not like any of these companies I'm referring to.
They try to squeeze every penny out of you that they can, and I said "cheap" servers for a reason. Sometimes the lag for certain games is unbearable and only people with extreme patience are able to play them.

That said... even though I've been a huge MR fan since #1, I won't play this game in any form, even if it were translated and even on good servers.
I hate MMO's and I can't stand that they want you to keep paying for a game that you already have.

By fiffa46 on Friday, April 13, 2007 - 02:01 pm:

I agree with the complete and utter dislike of makeing people pay to play a game they already paid for. I do play one game online, and all of the servers are run by players as the company who made the game abandoned it about 3 months after it was relesed. That company sence has gone out of buisness but there are still a core group of people who play the game. At any given time there are at least 4 player run servers up.
As far as monster rancher goes.......its a tough call. I love the series (dispite evo which I personally didn't like all that much) and want to continue to suport it. But I don't think I could afford to pay a monthly fee to play it.

By Gizmo the Lemur on Friday, April 13, 2007 - 03:16 pm:

Codemaster's is the only real company I know of that grabs MMOs from countries like Korea; unfortunately most said MMOs they have released suck. Most Korean/Asian MMOs are pretty bad because they still go by the long, horrible grinds and half-baked PvP systems (Wow's PvP has flaws, but it's playable and optional). It also doesn't help that most Asian companies tell their international customers to go "F" themsevles when someone gives them feedback or criticism when their games are getting hacked or rigged most of the time (FFXI with gilsellers making anything at endgame impossible and painful to do, PSO/U's hacking scene, etc.). You can't stop people from buying virtual money, but when you can't control the hacking and cheating going on...well... (just try to play Rakion, where you HAVE to cheat to win).

I actually like online games, and don't mind the fee because most [smart] companies try to improve and expand their games. I can barely sit through a single player game because my friends and I are either too busy to get together. At least with a PC game, you or a good fan base can mod the game to make it more fun or even fix it (You might want to read this line again, Lisa, since you went nuts with your stupid, crazy lawsuit threats to most of the MR fans*).

If the company goes out of it's way to address its players' needs while adding content (Blizzard, Funcom, Anet, and Sony do this, and even Squareenix does it now and then) I'm willing to pay $15/month for a game because it shows they care about the product.

That said, even if this comes out here, I dont'expect the game to be very good at all after seeing Phantasy Star Universe, Archlord, and Rising Force Online flop like a fish. I'm tired of playing a crappy Asian MMOs only to have it ruined by hacking/cheating, and rotten players (something that really killed PSU).

*Yeah, I went there.

By Zeta on Friday, April 13, 2007 - 07:29 pm:

Hrm. The new breeds are sort of cool. Elk, penguin, parrot, kitsune, rodent, another dragon breed, and Zan reworked into a humanoid scorpion.

By Zeta on Sunday, April 15, 2007 - 11:02 am:

The little Mocchi-like bunny is "Salamander", and the new dragon is Shiguniru. It seems the name is meant to be ironic since they have nothing to do with real or mythical salamanders - they're little arctic mammals with pink fur. There's a mention of Mocchi in Salamander's profile. Is this the replacement for it on online?

Most of the stuff is about game customization. The only stuff I personally found interesting was the note about the art released so far all taking place in the northern areas of the world, implying there might be a drastic change in climate that effects monsters in other areas.

By RPGDesigner on Friday, April 20, 2007 - 02:38 pm:

New update.

This time they're talking about the new additions to the website;
the music box, which has tracks from every MR game excluding
MR3, and a seven-page "tour" of sorts, which shows, among other
things, the regeneration process.

There's some nifty wallpaper at the end of it, too!

By RPGDesigner on Saturday, April 21, 2007 - 03:12 am:

Click on the second-to-last option on the top bar, between music
box and blog. A pop-up window will appear. Click on the picture to
bring up the seven-page feature.

The wallpaper can be found on page seven.

By Lisa Shock on Saturday, April 21, 2007 - 10:07 am:

Index Page Click on the next to the last link on the right side of the top bar to get the popup window. It's the one with the url ending in a #.
